titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Mart Albert Howard Papers and Photographs of the Klondike 1897-1915
Howard (Mart A.) Papers and Photographs of the Klondike
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Mary Avery and Lawrence Stark
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for encoding this finding aid was provided through a grant awarded by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

publicationstmt.publisher: Washington State University Libraries Manuscripts, Archives, and Special Collections

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Mark O'English 2003

repository.corpname: Washington State University Libraries, Manuscripts, Archives, and Special Collections

did.unittitle: Mart Albert Howard Papers and Photographs of the Klondike
did.abstract: Correspondence, diaries, financial and legal papers, photographs and lantern slides and other papers of Howard's experiences as a gold miner in the Klondike, 1898-1905.

bioghist.p: Mart A. Howard (1855-1926) was a businessman at Webster, Massachusetts in 1897 when news of the Klondike gold strikes reached the United States. He left from home in October of that year, taking a train to Portland, then on to Seattle where he outfitted for a trip to Alaska. Leaving Seattle in January 1898, he traveled north via coastal steamer to Dyea, then across Chilkoot Pass and along inland waterways to his eventual destination at Dawson, Yukon Territory. In the fall of the same year, he returned to Seattle and purchased a shipment of supplies, which he retailed in the Klondike the following spring. Using the profits of this mercantile venture, he became a mine operator, purchasing interests in various mines on the creeks north of Dawson. He returned briefly to Massachusetts in 1900 after which he took his third trip to the Klondike, this time accompanied by his wife and son. Howard remained in Dawson until 1905, after which he returned to Massachusetts permanently. In later years he became a public lecturer on the Klondike gold rush.

scopecontent.p: The papers of Mart Albert Howard, 1855-1926, consists of the correspondence, diaries, bills and receipts, legal documents and photographs which Howard, a Webster, Massachusetts, businessman, retained from his experience as a gold miner in the Klondike gold rush of 1897. Approximately two thirds of the collection are photographs taken by Howard or purchased from other Alaskan and Canadian photographers. Most photographs are glass-mounted transparencies.

accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research use.

prefercite.p: [Item Description]. Cage 63, Mart Albert Howard Papers and Photographs of the Klondike . Manuscripts, Archives, and Special Collections, Washington State University Libraries, Pullman, WA.

custodhist.p: Mart Howard's son Louis, who was 14 at the time of his trip to the Klondike and who was later Dean Of Mining at Washington State University, saved his father's papers until his own death in 1944. His widow then preserved the papers until she deposited then with the WSU Library in 1958.

acqinfo.p: The Howard Papers were acquired by the Washington State University Library in 1958 from Howard's daughter in law, Mrs. Louis O. Howard.

otherfindaid.p: A lengthy description of the papers in this collection may be found in Mary W. Avery, The Mart A. Howard Klondike Collection, Pacific Northwest Quarterly, 50 (1959) 53-62.

controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the online catalog. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons, or places should search the catalog using these headings.

controlaccess.geogname: Klondike River Valley (Yukon)--Gold discoveries -- Pictorial works

dsc.p: The following section contains a detailed listing of the materials in the collection.

did.unittitle: Series 1: Diaries, letters, papers, records, souvenirs, clippings
Letters of Mart Howard to wife and son in Webster, Mass.
Letters received by Mart Howard on business matters
Invoices and account book for purchases of supplies from Seattle and Klondike firms
Financial records of mining operations including profit and loss statement, "balance sheets" time books
Contracts, license, writs, deeds and other legal documents (included is 1860 permit to drive cattle through Dudley, Mass.
Souvenirs and mementos of southeast Alaska, Klondike region, including theater bills, boat menus and letterheads
General information regarding the territory of Alaska. Interior Dept.
Report on reduction of area of homesteads in Alaska to 160 acres, Interior Dept.
Mounted Newspaper clippings, re: Mart Howard; trial of George O'Brien at Dawson, Y.T.
Material for lectures on Klondike by Mart Howard
